contents.context:
Inter-Korean ties at the crossroads. Is this the end of it?
Let's get some analysis. Joining us live is Andrei Lankov, Professor at Koomin University and a North Korea expert trained at Kim Il-sung University in Pyeongyang.
Professor Lankov, thanks for linking up with us.



North Korea unleashed a fresh stream of threats and insults today pledging to dismantle the last remnants of President Moon Jae-in's legacy of rapprochement and move troops into disarmed border areas. First of all, if the North were to go ahead with that, it would effectively mean the end of the Moon administration's 2018 reconciliation efforts, would it not?

We also learned that President Moon had offered to send his national security adviser Chung Eui-yong and national intel service chief Suh Hoon to Pyeongyang as special envoys. Kim Yo-jong "flatly rejected calling it a tactless and sinister proposal." Is dialogue off the table?

The initial U.S. response was muted, with a senior administration official saying the American government was aware of the North Korean move and that the U.S. was in close coordination with its South Korean allies. How far will the North go if it doesn't draw a satisfactory response from the U.S.?

Andrei Lankov, Professor at Kookmin University and a North Korea expert many thanks for speaking with us this evening. We appreciate it.
Reporter : jenmoon@arirang.co.kr

So Hong Yoo, why the sudden resignation?

Connyoung, Unification Minister Kim Yeon-chul at 3pm today announced that he has offered to resign.
Speaking to reporters at the ministry, he said that he will take responsibility for the deteriorating inter-Korean relationship.
When quizzed by reporters about when he began to consider resigning,…he said that
there came a point when it was clear that the current situation was heading in a certain direction and he thought someone should take responsibility.
His resignation comes 14 months after his inauguration in April 2019.

Speaking of North Korea raising tensions,…what is the Unification Ministry's reaction to the statement made this morning by the General Staff of the North's Korean People's Army?

Unification Vice Minister, Suh Ho, was scheduled to visit the border area this Thursday as part of the government's efforts to stop anti-Pyeongyang leaflet-dropping.
But that was cancelled this afternoon because, according to a ministry source, the two Koreas are facing a "change" in their relationship which must be evaluated.
In response to the demolition of the inter-Korean Joint Liaison Office, the source said the government will soon come up with the right response to protect its national property rights.
In a special address this morning, the Vice Minister said North Korea's recent statement has set the inter-Korean relationship back to how it was before their first-ever summit.
The vice-minister added that North Korea will be responsible for the deteriorating relationship and urged Pyeongyang not to take measures that could worsen the situation
Let's take a listen:

"Our government expresses deep regret over the North's statement, noting that it will deploy military units to the Mount Geumgang tourism zone and Gaeseong Industrial Complex. The North should take due responsibility for its actions. We urge the North to stop further exacerbating the situation."

He said the two Koreas had agreed through the September 2018 'Pyeongyang Joint Declaration' to first normalize the Gaeseong Industrial Complex and the Mount Geumgang Tourism Project as conditions improve.
He added, Seoul has worked at ways to improve inter-Korean cooperation such as the possibility of individual tours to the North and business visits to Gaeseong Industrial Complex.
That's all I have at this hour, back to you Connyoung.

This small town called Myeongpa-ri is just 10 kilometers from the military demarcation line that divides the two Koreas.
Located in Gosung County, Gangwon-do Province, this neighborhood is on high alert due to rising tensions stemming from the North's latest bombing of the joint liaison office.
People are trying to farm their land, run their businesses, and live like normal.
And they are still allowed to cross the Civilian Control Line.

But fears are spreading in the community, following the North's announcement that it would mobilize troops in the demilitarized zone and the special tourism zone around Mount Geumgang.

At another border area, Yeonpyeong-do lsland, things are bit more tense.
Just off the coast of Gyeonggi-do Province, the island was the target of a North Korean artillery attack 10 years ago.
As of Wednesday, soldiers have been dispatched across the island.
Public officials are inspecting evacuation facilities which are currently closed due to COVID-19.
They are also informing residents on emergency guidelines.

It's a similar scene in the city of Paju, one of the places designated by Gyeonggi-do Province as a "critical region".
In Daesung-dong, the only civilian village inside the South's demilitarized zone, residents are living under fear and uncertainty after actually hearing Tuesday's explosion.

And they have another concern their struggling local businesses could be hit harder by the further drop in tourism due to the tensions.

To help these people feel safe, local governments and police services are upping their inspections to prevent the sending of anti-Pyeongyang leaflets, which are believed to be the source of the ongoing tensions.
Lee Kyung-eun, Arirang News.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com

North Korea claims to have rejected South Korea's offer to send a special envoy to Pyeongyang in light of the flare up in tensions on the Korean Peninsula.
It labeled it an unrealistic offer and one that won't fool them.
For more, we connect to our presidential office correspondent Kim Min-ji.
Min-ji, has Seoul's top office said anything in response?

Semin, no word yet from South Korea's presidential office.
But on Tuesday, a top Blue House official said he had not heard discussions of sending a special envoy, although Seoul's offers for inter-Korean cooperation or a potential summit remain open.
So we'll have to wait and see what today's response is like.
Just this morning, the North's state media said Kim Yo-jong, the sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un had flatly rejected South Korea's offer to send a special envoy calling it a sinister proposal.
It said the South Korean side sent a message that President Moon Jae-in wanted to send special envoys Chung Eui-yong, the Director of National Security and Suh Hoon, the head of the nation's intel agency to meet Chairman Kim.
And referring to President Moon as the ruler of South Korea, it criticized what it claimed to be a "nonsensical approach," saying it doesn't work on them.
It added that Kim Yo-jong warned that South Korea should stop making unrealistic offers, but rather take appropriate action.

Separately, in a statement, Kim Yo-jong criticized President Moon's message of cooperation and exchange between the two sides to mark twenty years since the first-ever inter-Korean summit.
She said Monday's message contained no measures to resolve the current situation -- saying South Korea's failure to stop activists sending propaganda leaflets across the border sparked the tensions.
She added it was Seoul that had failed to abide by the Panmunjeom Declaration to end all hostilities adding they can no longer discuss inter-Korean relations.

The developments and the speed at which this is unfolding are a shock no doubt for the Moon administration that had been reaching out to the North, despite Tuesday's warning of strong action in response to any move that would worsen the situation on the peninsula.
That's all I have at this hour, back to you Semin.
